document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills in Social Studies

C1AF38FA201D44E4869062483B08B290.description: Social studies skills. The student uses problem-solving and decision-making skills, working independently and with others. The student is expected to use problem-solving and decision-making processes to identify a problem, gather information, list and consider options, consider advantages and disadvantages, choose and implement a solution, and evaluate the effectiveness of the solution.

1047D0E499E74F96BE23035A46BD9890.description: pose and answer questions about geographic distributions and patterns shown on maps, graphs, charts, and available databases.

A6B10CA67D294656ADDD310AB4D9F6C7.description: create a visual representation of historical information such as thematic maps, graphs, and charts; and

EC92FD1E6DF740D88205E8ED9BF1763C.description: Social studies skills. The student uses geographic tools to collect, analyze, and interpret data. The student is expected to:

0ED854D55D65445CA81A11B97DC23F6C.description: create written, oral, and visual presentations of social studies information using effective communication skills, including proper citations and avoiding plagiarism; and

6CE52570D28F41D398431FC7306A2BDF.description: Social studies skills. The student communicates in written, oral, and visual forms. The student is expected to:

9FB852CC735249D496B1CD6AAD5DC103.description: identify bias and support with historical evidence a point of view on a social studies issue or event.

AF33941F8CF8437EB00E01E15743420C.description: evaluate the validity of a source based on corroboration with other sources and information about the author, including points of view, frames of reference, and historical context; and

62A005377A664D3585A98CB3EFAFEC60.description: apply the process of historical inquiry to research, interpret, and use multiple types of sources of evidence;

6BF879DF1EDE4C4AB293C55B387EA220.description: analyze information by applying absolute and relative chronology through sequencing, categorizing, identifying cause-and-effect relationships, comparing and contrasting, finding the main idea, summarizing, making generalizations, making predictions, drawing inferences, and drawing conclusions;

0986400D20B14D878ACF21276A0C5540.description: analyze primary and secondary sources such as maps, graphs, speeches, political cartoons, and artifacts to acquire information to answer historical questions;

EA2C9F1C40D2402083E50D1615DA440B.description: Social studies skills. The student understands how historians use historiography to interpret the past and applies critical-thinking skills to organize and use information acquired from a variety of valid sources, including technology. The student is expected to:

7F619821F70A4BCCAA26A91F9E25FF8F.description: describe the contributions of significant African American individuals to science, philosophy, mathematics, and technology such as Benjamin Banneker, George Washington Carver, Granville Woods, Mary Jackson, Katherine Johnson, Henrietta Lacks, Dorothy Vaughan, Mae Jemison, and Neil deGrasse Tyson.

1E6AE98899374DF5AEB725F2AB3CDB57.description: identify examples of how industrialization was influenced by African Americans over time; and

5AF9A30461724BC1ADBC4FEA8E8CDC8B.description: identify examples of how advances made by African civilizations in areas such as astronomy, mathematics, architecture, and engineering have contributed to science and technology in the United States;

AC1BAD27C21542AFBD559AE593638C3F.description: Science, technology, and society. The student understands how African American achievements in science and technology have contributed to economic and social development in the United States. The student is expected to:

EE0228A64F5143689BF609F07D0B343D.description: describe contemporary issues in education for African American students such as the school-to-prison pipeline, opportunity gaps, overrepresentation in special education, and underrepresentation in gifted and talented opportunities.

72E4BF2A8F0A48B1BAE3633927784A5C.description: analyze the expansion of educational opportunities for African Americans, including the Freedman's Bureau, Rosenwald Schools, the Second Morrill Act (1890), the establishment of Historically Black Colleges and Universities, and the role of the National Pan-Hellenic Council (Divine 9); and

4C44F33CAA804B26954F15987738151E.description: describe the efforts to prevent the education of enslaved people and free African Americans, including anti-literacy laws;

D743E193F35B494E9B4CB5A13482BBB8.description: Culture. The student understands African American educational developments, achievements, and opportunities before and after the U.S. Supreme Court decision of Brown v. Board of Education (1954). The student is expected to:

0B874F1FB5544BB7AD03644E9BE0583E.description: analyze the impact of popular culture on African Americans during significant eras.

9B9F4B30056E47A4B110653409ECD231.description: describe how characteristics of African American history and culture have been reflected in various genres of art, music, film, theatre, visual arts, and dance; and

8B523E68904045F6B9884CF87386312E.description: describe storytelling, literary, filmmaking, and visual arts contributions related to self-identity made by African Americans such as Oscar Micheaux, John T. Biggers, James Baldwin, Lorraine Hansberry, Amiri Baraka, Sidney Poitier, Maya Angelou, Faith Ringgold, August Wilson, bell hooks, Spike Lee, John Singleton, and Oprah Winfrey;

5B8DE6BA70CF49DB996D3AEE93FC67F6.description: describe the reactions to and the influence of selected works by African American authors such as The Souls of Black Folk by W.E.B. Du Bois, Native Son by Richard Wright, Their Eyes Were Watching God by Zora Neale Hurston, Beloved by Toni Morrison, and Eyes on the Prize by Henry Hampton;

FF33FBEC82A04CD8AF313299F8FC1016.description: explain the lasting impact of the Harlem Renaissance on American culture and society such as the achievements of Louis Armstrong, Josephine Baker, Duke Ellington, Langston Hughes, Sargent Johnson, Jules Bledsoe, Paul Robeson, Augusta Savage, and James VanDerZee;

D629A7E4213049A587A61FB133539BEE.description: describe how various African American expressions of dance forms such as tap dance, step dance, hip hop, and modern dance and the contributions of African American dancers such as the Dance Theater of Harlem, Katherine Dunham, Bill "Bojangles" Robinson, Alvin Ailey, and Misty Copeland have contributed to the shared identity of various groups;

45E47FAC84E640AEA2D249F0562F0CAC.description: describe the development and influence of blues, ragtime, jazz, and hip hop music such as the achievements of composers Scott Joplin and James Reese Europe;

5374B9B3554B404CAFD71A13ADB64149.description: Culture. The student understands the influence of artistic expression on the African American experience and American culture from Reconstruction to the present. The student is expected to:

4426702C8B1242BB93139A812AFAD8C6.description: describe the expanding influence of African American music through the work of performers such as the Fisk Jubilee Singers.

C5F4F90E56634598BD010B17F1709F80.description: explain the origins and characteristics of different musical genres and traditions of African Americans; and

087F1C9F0C204C6194824B9D486DF7DD.description: identify the contributions of early African American literature, including the works of Jupiter Hammon and Phillis Wheatley;

65BD9ADAC81748B9BD2A56D9ECE5FE53.description: describe the influence of enslavement on African American culture;

AC215FB60693470E9B567B2516C1B18F.description: identify and describe the influence of African oral traditions, visual art, literary art, theater, music, and dance on African American culture;

241B522F0D184D93BE437C9B151FBF44.description: Culture. The student understands the cultural traditions and contributions of African Americans from the colonial era through Reconstruction. The student is expected to:

7F1339C3B6AD45E39EE36F8895BDBA8B.description: analyze the various cultural practices that have shaped the individual and collective identity of African Americans over time to understand shared and differing experiences.

641FAD413A5047919DCD43F424AE28C7.description: analyze ways in which African Americans have retained cultural identity over time while adapting to and contributing to mainstream American culture; and

145FDE1C6B9C4F6CB1F3472D2212EF63.description: analyze the impact of assimilation, stereotypes, de facto practices, and oppression on the lives of African Americans;

F63AC50A6CD647F4B4813C1B1C4E6F7F.description: Culture. The student understands the development of African American culture and society and the impact of shared identities and differing experiences. The student is expected to:

66A6AD546A0C4C40AA51E402D60CD6E2.description: identify and describe the diversity of peoples of African ancestry such as Afro-Latinos, Afro-Caribbeans, and recent African immigrants.

F39C2CE69CD44A0BB88A16A3EAED9CFE.description: analyze selected contemporary African American issues that have led to diverse points of view in public discourse, including rights and activism; and

3D0EB28EDA734E4398C6BB81FEE2EB19.description: analyze the significance and associations of identity nomenclature relevant to African Americans such as Negro and Black;

C8FFC81323B84EE281F84AA43BE17CEA.description: analyze how regional differences influenced political perspectives of African American communities;

06D401C4A08A422282D33C7CC7ACD453.description: trace how perceptions of the rights and civic responsibilities of African Americans have changed over time, including the idea of being considered property with no rights under slavery;

0E921B575B5A479F95507C3D013EB7F5.description: Citizenship. The student understands the importance of multiple and changing points of view regarding citizenship of African Americans. The student is expected to:

54867E606B234890A5BA277EFBCC7BEA.description: identify the contributions of African American leaders at local, state, and national levels of government.

E6785B8CD22B4938B3E77ADB83C014DB.description: explain how various philosophies and ideologies influenced the African American experience for social, political, and legal equality such as fair housing, equal opportunity, affirmative action, and voting rights; and

33E2CE8F96904E5EB905D176BAF5C90C.description: analyze examples of conflict and cooperation between African Americans and other groups in the pursuit of individual freedoms and civil rights such as the Freedom Riders and the Memphis Sanitation Workers Strike;

D87DE14246D14FE3B9CE2F5DB640CD61.description: Government. The student understands the impact of political interactions on the African American struggle for human rights over time. The student is expected to:

F8E450E9A1FE472885F94D38EE5EEB3E.description: analyze how the changing political environment has impacted civil rights from the late 20th century to the present.

22D6D2E3A93F4A898FCC4AD7CF83A513.description: analyze the causes and effects of government actions and legislation addressing racial and social injustices from 1960 to the present day such as the issues of voting rights, civil rights, fair housing, education, employment, affirmative action, the War on Crime, the War on Drugs, mass incarceration, and health and nutrition; and

D7433AA4AEC74A94A6044F956DEEDE7C.description: analyze how government policies, court actions, and legislation impacted African Americans from the 1920s through the 1950s;

7989EEF8EA2D4A639080404DDF4CB0CB.description: analyze the construction, interpretation, and implementation of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments to the U.S. Constitution and the effects on African American men and women between 1877 and 1920;

2869AF65DBDF46B7825F81C9B0372674.description: explain the regional perspectives toward political rights of African American men and women from the early years of the republic through 1877;

F643F1000E3346B386ADACAD8175DBDE.description: compare and contrast how political perspectives of free and enslaved African Americans in the late 1700s and early 1800s were influenced by the unalienable rights expressed in the Declaration of Independence and civil rights in the Bill of Rights;

0B2CACAA848D4A5C937452F205406F6D.description: Government. The student understands the significant impact of political decisions on African Americans throughout history. The student is expected to:

08D4580DE5A1483C9FA24F21AFA819EF.description: examine the contributions of African American and Black American Business entrepreneurship such as Black Wall Street, black inventors, and the black experience in business and the economic contributions of individuals such as Madame C. J. Walker and Maggie L. Walker.

F409350C23ED412D86307F6D8616AE1F.description: trace the rise and development African American businesses and entrepreneurship from the late 19th century to today; and

B068B14902E64B2C9DE79193FAD17450.description: evaluate the effectiveness of various approaches African Americans have used to solve economic issues;

27734179C0A44BDC95604B5C754B3944.description: analyze how various geographic, cultural, social, political, and financial factors influenced the economic mobility of African Americans such as skin color, wealth, and educational background;

F4FB562C78B74A8A957C8CFFE232ED87.description: evaluate the economic impact of the American labor movement and unionism on African Americans from the late nineteenth century to today;

0014362AD5144C83A893E84AA2B6DCBE.description: explain how economic conditions and racism contributed to the Great Migration;

1BCB7BB3E8A747AE83AAD2F10E32235A.description: explain how sharecropping and redlining limited economic opportunities for African Americans;

2D92A68D27304A749E9374E81786B701.description: analyze the effects of the Industrial Revolution and the roles of "King Cotton" and the cotton gin in the economies of the United States and the world;

847106772646431AAA69547A60BE4235.description: Economics. The student understands ways in which African Americans have addressed opportunities, challenges, and strategies concerning economic well-being over time. The student is expected to:

87084C31A5FC44EAB394C9AD564292E9.description: analyze how environmental changes impacted African American communities such as land use, settlement patterns, and urban development.

8FE7EF5A331344C2A656E0ED5C2EAB65.description: explain the westward movement and the Great Migration and summarize their impact on African Americans; and

B7937E384B7342D78C26EDC3B2DE8A85.description: identify and explain the physical and human geographic factors that contributed to the Atlantic Slave Trade, the rise of the plantation system in the South, the development of textile mills in the North, and economic interdependence between the North and South;

5A180DEFD26641B8BA1FC8BA157834CE.description: explain the causes and effects of forced and voluntary migration on individuals, groups, and societies throughout African American history;

64BAC04F472B40188788E880B5AF2E01.description: Geography. The student understands the impact of geographic factors on major events related to African Americans over time. The student is expected to:

9E915EB78231426EAECDAD1B29E67018.description: analyze the progress and challenges for African American men and women socially, economically, and politically from 1970 to the present such as the evolving role of education in the African American community.

F9AFDF31CC1748F4A85DF85C97BEBB40.description: describe the major achievements of contemporary African Americans and how their contributions have shaped the American experience such as John H. Johnson, Muhammad Ali, Fannie Lou Hamer, Shirley Chisholm, Earl G. Graves, Barbara Jordan, Colin Powell, Condoleezza Rice, and Barack Obama; and

67794B324928452FA4589F80D7DE6AF6.description: identify and explain the issues confronting African Americans in the continuing effort to achieve equality;

C800F56676224D328EDC8A4390A2C4B2.description: History. The student understands the progress made and challenges faced by African Americans from the post-Civil Rights Era to contemporary times. The student is expected to:

DDF2E396C2184248A873B8394DEE61CB.description: evaluate the extent to which the Civil Rights Movement transformed American politics and society.

206CAED2BBA04101931D8434BF3B0D92.description: analyze the successes, failures, and ongoing impact of the Civil Rights Movement, including methods such as sit-ins, boycotts, marches, speeches, music, and organizations; and

A0BB1BC8EBAE41079ACFABE824F9E977.description: analyze how the effects of World War II laid the groundwork for the Civil Rights Movement such as Harry S. Truman's Executive Order 9981 and the contributions of A. Phillip Randolph, Mary McLeod Bethune, and Thurgood Marshall;

DF7551329B3D4B22A3DBC19B402B9783.description: explain the contributions of significant African American individuals and groups during World War II, including Doris "Dorie" Miller, the Tuskegee Airmen, and the 761st Tank Battalion;

38FA959DE49C4BF79F5425DB997FD626.description: describe the impact of racism during World War II;

DA8A0518D8B54D8280D5B8924D909FC0.description: describe the interactions of the people of the diaspora relative to the struggle for civil rights;

BE743F855A544D33841DBB0EB498ACFD.description: describe the continued struggle for civil rights in America during this time in history such as the notable works of the NAACP, National Urban League, Jackie Robinson, Rosa Parks, Martin Luther King Jr., Daisy Bates and the Little Rock Nine, the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), and local leaders;

5218EDF24D4249B696FDB3FFB4A76A38.description: describe the impact of U.S. Supreme Court decisions Sweatt v. Painter (1950) and Brown v. Board of Education (1954);

9C149EC34BDA4D3EA5DE9E9643AAF81B.description: compare the positive and negative effects of the Great Depression and New Deal on the social and economic status of African Americans in various geographic regions;

3CAE01AA3AE3446E8EBE8E08B185E1AC.description: History. The student understands change and continuity in the African American cultural identity during the Great Depression, World War II, and the Civil Rights Movement. The student is expected to:

2D42D885E55E4D14B6A34A3B5B34BE39.description: describe the impact of African American military service from Reconstruction through World War I, including the role of the Buffalo Soldiers.

50EEC64C425F40A3B368135DBA116E00.description: examine the experiences of African American soldiers during and after World War I; and

31149C507A0A4217B70F3955F3F0E312.description: analyze the social, economic, and political actions of African Americans in response to the Jim Crow era during the early 20th century such as the Great Migration, civil rights organizations, social organizations, political organizations, and organized labor unions;

4CF3C3D69DAD406D823D41B6E6C30D66.description: describe the impact of the U.S. Supreme Court decision Plessy v. Ferguson (1896);

F64AC4C1459341A590EC572C3D2F398B.description: explain how the rise of Jim Crow laws affected the life experiences of African Americans in the late 19th and early 20th centuries;

137D01AF45F04B75ADA13E316A095820.description: explain the impact of the convict leasing system on African Americans such as the Sugar Land 95;

684976AD40254691B4D6AA5ABD48C671.description: explain the circumstances surrounding increased violence and extremism such as the Ku Klux Klan (KKK), the Colfax Massacre, lynchings, race riots, and the Camp Logan Mutiny (The Houston Riot of 1917);

571E8E33016C45A69E930C98D8A432C8.description: compare the opportunities and challenges faced by African Americans from post-Reconstruction to the early 20th century and viewpoints and actions of African Americans, including Ida B. Wells, W.E.B. Du Bois, Booker T. Washington, Marcus Garvey, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), Freedmen's Towns, and the Exodusters;

5F64F2407A0446698C6BF07CF0718C3C.description: describe and analyze the successes and failures of Reconstruction;

9658F79E5092415AB0733A20B2102436.description: summarize the roles and experiences of African American soldiers and spies in both the North and South during the Civil War;

90314D023AB3420091F9B8BF88F3693E.description: History. The student understands African American life from the Civil War through World War I. The student is expected to:

5E03857DEDEA4798BE056CD37C3A442C.description: analyze national and international abolition efforts, including the gradual emancipation of enslaved people in the North (1777-1804), the U.S. ban on the slave trade (1808), the abolition of slavery in Mexico (1829) and Great Britain (1833), and the significance of the Guerrero Decree in the Texas Revolution.

9DA985F217854A9C9482826871133B00.description: analyze the influence of significant individuals and groups prior to and during the abolitionist movement to determine their impact on ending slavery such as the work of David Walker, Elijah P. Lovejoy, John Brown, Sojourner Truth, Frederick Douglass, the American Anti-Slavery Society, and the Underground Railroad; and

91B8360BE8834C71A325036F0FEA685B.description: analyze and evaluate various forms of individual and group resistance against the enslavement of African Americans;

96F225F574784CE6BF153E7C0C23805A.description: analyze the role that slavery played in the development of nationalism and sectionalism during the early 19th century;

AD8F567D8B914B0586AACFB82FCD866F.description: describe the impact of the Three-Fifths Compromise and the Fugitive Slave Act;

901770F9A64D46D8AD51D52D428390E5.description: analyze the economic, social, religious, and legal rationalization used by some Americans to continue and expand slavery after declaring independence from Great Britain;

C0F868376D9E466499F9938FCD7289D7.description: History. The student understands the rationalization and ramifications for the continuation and growth of slavery and the anti-slavery movement in the United States from independence (1776) through the Emancipation Proclamation (1863). The student is expected to:

9BB18421578949B5BE9E7289A15D5369.description: explain the causes for the growth and development of slavery, primarily in the Southern colonies.

DF23429A9DC3436FAE034C6193F79098.description: describe and explain the impact of the Middle Passage on African American culture; and

04C5AA03F9264C89B67BD903673D07DA.description: compare and contrast the colonization of North, Central, and South America and the West Indies and neighboring islands and analyze the interactions among enslaved Africans and Native Americans;

C46CD69923BC4A4599A0493E081B706A.description: analyze the African diaspora, including the role of Africans and Europeans;

E70FAFC930AC4EA497A4E704C4B10610.description: History. The student understands the economic, political, and social development of slavery during the American colonial period, 1619 to 1775. The student is expected to:

34DB44C41CD64B15AAB5DFF1179F6D6C.description: analyze the effects of dehumanization through the capture, trade, and enslavement of Africans, within a regional and global context, including the Atlantic Slave Trade.

9193A0A95D0B4E0F9F73746903EE4F79.description: describe and compare the various pre-colonial, indigenous, and ancestral roots of African Americans such as educational systems, social and political developments, family structures, global trade, and exchange; and

AC5E2C913ABE48F98A5CCA71B551882F.description: identify the major eras, civilizations, and contributions of African history that are foundational to humanity and predate American slavery;

B311156C4FA2422393AB3C594626736E.description: History. The student understands the influential historical points of reference in African history prior to 1619. The student is expected to
